# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Special Instructions

{{instructions}}

You can use the `@pip install DataFrames` package in Julia to create, manipulate and analyze data. This package is very user-friendly and has a lot of useful functionalities including filtering and manipulating the DataFrame objects. 

Below is the code to solve the problem:

```julia
using DataFrames

function audi_filter(df_cars::DataFrame)
    # filter out only rows with manufacturer "audi" and model as "a4" or "a4 quattro"
    df_new = filter(row -> row.manufacturer == "audi" && (row.model == "a4" || row.model == "a4 quattro"), df_cars)
    
    # create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals true across all rows 
    df_new[:audi_a4_type] = true
    
    return df_new
end
```

You can call this function on your DataFrame like so:

```julia
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "bmw", "audi", "mercedes-benz"], model=["a4", "320i", "a4 quattro", "c class"])
filtered_dataframe = audi_filter(df_cars)
```
